title: Tesla earnings special edition
openingHTML: Come chat about earnings, capital raises (or lack thereof) and Elon Musk.

teaser.title: Markets Live:  Tesla earnings special edition

bodyHTML:
9:00 pm
AS9:00pm

Welcome to markets live y'all -- not much to discuss huh?

SupposeToBeWorking... Hi all
Driss hi
AS9:01pm

just kidding it's Elon Musk Day

JP9:02pm

Good evening, isn't it always Elon Musk day?

9:02 pm
AS9:02pm

obviously

AS9:02pm

See also: https://www.mcswee...ng-about-elon-musk

Ken M If it isn't Elon Musk wants it to be.
AS9:03pm

First point -- it's a bit odd is that he's been so intense with the "WE'RE NOT RAISING CAPITAL" line

Ken M See also: https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/990854677926297600
DJ62 Hi all, when does EM make his presentations?
9:03 pm
JP9:04pm

That piece was a little too close to the bone for me.

JP9:04pm

Yes, particularly as Bloomberg calculate Tesla are burning, oh, you know, around $6,500 per minute

Driss comment on possible SEC investigation?
Brutto Hello, positional goods fans..
AS9:05pm

and because they have a not-insignificant amount of convertible debt maturing in the next 12 months

9:05 pm
JP9:05pm

how much roughly Alex?

MontanaSkeptic Hello, all
SupposeToBeWorking... And they aren't making any cars? It's actually not clear to be if that helps with the cash burn or not....
JP9:07pm

well Musk has found one source of liquidity over the past quarter, a $541m lease-backed bond. Any takers?

Brutto Just trying to figure out at which level to short Tesla...ideas?
MontanaSkeptic There are $82.5MM of Solar Bonds maturing in August. Held by Musk & Rive. And $230MM of Solar City bonds in November, IIRC
JP9:08pm

Brutto, we do not advise on shorting religions.

9:08 pm
AS9:08pm

btw it looks like our comment moderators are out to lunch (or at the pub) so apologies if things are stuck on pending

Brutto Someone bought over 1000 January 2020 put contracts (100 shares each contract) at $50...
Ken M Stock is trading up 1% after hours
Driss wonder if elons going to show up late again
Ken M That's probably against CDS.
Ken M The puts I mean.
JP9:10pm

Oh dear, let's speed that up.

AS9:10pm

but MontanaSkeptic I did see those $230m SCTY bonds maturing in November

Brutto Good point Ken M
bones30 https://twitter.com/PresidentOprahW/status/991770236310491138This is fun ^
9:10 pm
AS9:10pm

by bonds i mean converts

AS9:10pm

and well, they are... not in the money

JP9:10pm

that's quite a chunk

Claudius They may be "reinventing" the car, but they've done the industry of bad conference call hold music no favors
9:11 pm
AS9:11pm

looks like the conversion price is somewhere north of $500

MontanaSkeptic Yes, the SCTY $230MM converts due Nov '18 are way, way out of the money. And I think Musk, with "strong positive operating cash flow" in Q3, will take the opportunity to repay himself and his cousin. One other cousin was already paid in February.
Ken M up 2% now.
JP9:12pm

the boring stuff: consensus EPS is -$3.42, consensus revenue is $3.3bn, consensus cash burn is close to $1bn and estimated gross margin, one to watch, is 14.5%

Brutto Hurrah! Those puts are getting cheaper...
AS9:12pm

But if they're held by Musk and Rive they shouldn't have much trouble getting a refinancing done. (or... paying themselves? tho i can't imagine that'd help cash flow. if Musk cares.)

Ken M LOL
9:13 pm
JP9:13pm

Here are the numbers...

AS9:13pm

aand it's out -- adjusted loss per share of $3.35

AS9:14pm

which is... a beat, I guess?

Ken M Looks like the fanboy are piling in to the falcon 9.
9:14 pm
JP9:14pm

I think we should count that as a beat

JP9:15pm

here is the Q1 letter http://files.share...Letter_2018-1Q.pdf

Ken M Model 3 production up to 2270/wk.
That New Car Smell Excited to be here!
AS9:15pm

2018 Capex projection reduced from

$3.4 billion to <$3 billion

Brutto Here's the plan: at £1,000 (refundable?) deposit per Model 3 it should be reasonably easy to inflate the order book...
9:15 pm
AS9:16pm

(unclear why there's a quote within the quote above, sorry guys)

Ken M Well, that's them taking themselves out of the need to raise capital. Just stop invessting.
JP9:16pm

projecting positive cash flow in Q3 and Q4, any thoughts?

JP9:17pm

however this is contingent on...

9:17 pm
JP9:17pm

This is primarily based on our ability to reach
Model 3 production volume of 5,000 units per week and to grow Model 3 gross margin from slightly negative in Q1 2018 to close to
breakeven in Q2 and then to highly positive in Q3 and Q4

AS9:17pm

... should also point out that automotive gross margin is down 766 bp from 1Q last year

JP9:18pm

it is also worth pointing out that Tesla calculate their auto gross margin quite differently to other auto companies

9:18 pm
AS9:18pm

that was the GAAP-approved version above

Edward Quince Lots of forward-looking statements for a Q1 earnings release, no?
Brutto Luckily for Elon no other car manufacturer has thought of entering his market..
Ken M Shares are now negative.
Brutto So that negative gross margin might turn eventually...and fall straight through to the bottom line because all other costs are exceptional...
Ken M I think the typical TSLA shareholder is probably not psyched about the capex reduction announcement. It means that the high margin flying/self-driving cars may not come on line soon enough.
itme color: more sellers than buyers
JP9:21pm

The gross margin point, they do not include R&D or neither do they discount their cars to sell to dealers, like other auto companies.

JP9:22pm

Capex reduction is interesting, because it is not clear where the Semi or the Y are going to be built. Neither mentioned in the quarterly update.

9:22 pm
JP9:22pm

maybe we'll get granularity on the conference call

SupposeToBeWorking... Also not clear how much work is still needed to redo the model 3 line...
Ken M Seriously, TSLA always rockets on new product announcement (semi-tractor trailer eg) so reduction in capex takes some of the shine off the stock.
JP9:24pm

SupposeToBeWorking, it seems they are planning more downtime at Fremont - although at least this time we know about it, before you know, on the day...

JP9:25pm

In order to achieve this production rate, we plan to take additional
days of downtime during Q2, just like we did in Q1. We have already done this several times during the Model 3 ramp, including once in the third week of April to fix several small, known constraints, enabling higher levels of output.

9:25 pm
AS9:25pm

very brief comments about buffalo

AS9:25pm

Our Solar Roof facility in Buffalo continued to ramp in Q1. We are working to enhance the product design and manufacturing process
in order to improve the customer experience while reducing manufacturing cost and achieving high levels of quality. Production of
Solar Roofs should accelerate significantly in the second half of this year.

AS9:26pm

fairly vague too!

Claudius Do we know what Wall St's projection for Q2 and FY production was/is?
9:25 pm
JP9:26pm

ah yes, the solar roof

AS9:26pm

all that sweet NY state money

JP9:26pm

what ever happened to that? I remember that presser on wisteria lane

Brutto @Ken M ..that ,and Elon awarding himself some huge option package at some moonshot valuation: and sells it as "eating his own cooking"..so he must be confident, no?
Robert Smith what's the HYB doing?
9:26 pm
AS9:27pm

translates into .... "continued to ramp" and lots of Panasonic activity

JP9:27pm

the Buffalo Plant is a bit of an elephant in the room

Brutto Solar Roofs - and isn't there a battery factory tucked away somewhere as well..?
AS9:27pm

great question Rob Smith!

bones30 Wasn't there something about a TSLA music streaming service?
MontanaSkeptic Negative working capital ($1.1B in Q1) has more than doubled (to $2.3B) in Q2.Biggest contributor is $1.1B increase in current portion of long-term debt and capital leases. $300MM or so for debt owed to insider & SCTY bonds due in November, but what's the rest?
Malcolm Tucker What about the Tesla Network?
9:28 pm
JP9:28pm

bones30 - oh yes, forgot about that one

Malcolm Tucker Or the Tesla Production System?
That New Car Smell Elon is an ideas machine
JP9:29pm

I mean they could just team up with Spotify, but why bother when you can do it all yourself?

AS9:29pm

the Tesla 2025 bond is pretty steady from 4pm levels but up for the day

Brutto @Malcolm Tucker all we need now is a Tesla Blockchain and we are made
Robert Smith cool! at what cash px? still high 80s?
Malcolm Tucker Give it time...
bones30 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0oV4IVy8tvE"Doors that do this"
SupposeToBeWorking... What about Grohmann Engineering? Or Tesla Grohmann automation as they've now renamed it. They could have kept Mr Grohman, avoided the union disputes, and got some good cash flow if they hadn't torpedoed all Grohmanns contracts....
Sean Wagner Interesting: the Grohmann line isn't required for the ramp to 5'000 Model 3s per week.
9:30 pm
AS9:31pm

bumping up against 89 Rob... rally hat time amirite?

Malcolm Tucker Yes, wasn't that all supposed to be installed in Nevada to unclog the only thing holding back Model 3 production?
JP9:31pm

looking at the energy generation and storage revenue, gross margins still very compressed

AS9:31pm

Rocket

bones30 JP: was it a subtle tell that the ideas machine was running out of them?
MontanaSkeptic Tesla has increased its A/P, Customer deposits, and Accrued expenses by $510MM, and borrowed another $370MM through debt facilities. Not exactly a sustainable formula.
9:31 pm
JP9:31pm

Q1 2017 was 29.1%, Q1 2018 was err, 8.5%

AS9:31pm

literal LOL bones30

alphaisbeta Somebody needs to ask them how walking back from automation uber alles to "human beings are good" impacts gross margins. I can't imagine its a good thing.
AS9:32pm

operating expenses up 14% from last year -- and as MontanaSkeptic says a nice comment that, annoyingly, remains pending:

9:32 pm
AS9:33pm

Tesla has increased its A/P, Customer deposits, and Accrued expenses by $510MM, and borrowed another $370MM through debt facilities. Not exactly a sustainable formula.

JP9:33pm

very interesting

JP9:34pm

also saw Energy Store revenue is up nearly 98% YoY, due to the revenue cognition of that much heralded Australia installation

9:34 pm
JP9:35pm

who knew solar would work in Southern Australia, rite?

Malcolm Tucker Minor question, how does a car go from negative margins to hugely positive ones in six months?
Driss magic
AS9:36pm

so it could be possible that i'm reading too far into the choice of words in this letter

JP9:36pm

go on Alex...

Sean Wagner Malcolm, that's how I understood things too. It was meant to be shipped already, if I understood infos correctly. But it's never as easy as testing, disassemlbing, reassembling, and toggle a switch.Re margins, easy - that's what a production ramp is meant to achieve. Ask Boeing.
9:36 pm
AS9:36pm

Cash outflow from operating activities in Q1 2018 was $398 million primarily due to an increase in inventory and accounts
receivable balances as a result of the timing of deliveries.

AS9:37pm

but just saying

AS9:37pm

it did take me a couple of reads to realize they were talking about ~negative~ cash

MontanaSkeptic Why the increase in "Customer deposits"? My guess is this: "Short-term operational and logistical issues led to an increase in the number of Model S and Model X vehicles in transit to customers at the end of Q1." Payment for all those vehicles in transit is part of "Customer deposits."
Brutto Good question Malcolm - at gross margin level making cars isn't exactly a fixed cost game, where you start making money the more you build...
9:38 pm
JP9:38pm

sorry again for the pending comments, we have mobilised the FT tech army. should be sorted soon.

Ken M I'll bet the reduction in automation was partially driven by the need to reduce capex to conserve cash.
Malcolm Tucker I mean, parts and materials aren't going to get significantly cheaper and if they're running three shifts at Fremont manufacturing certainly isn't going to be cheaper...
itme my pending comments are just me saying Scaggggsssss repeatedly
JP9:39pm

Tesla also managed to squeeze another $50.3m of ZEV credits out of this quarter

JP9:40pm

which is folded in to their GAAP Gross Profit

9:40 pm
JP9:40pm

can anyone tell me why Tesla add-back stock compensation to their non-GAAP automotive gross profit?

Malcolm Tucker It all sounds like a lot of deckchair rearrangement
Sean Wagner Ken M, I don't think so. The reduction in automation was from sheer necessity of finding means to assemble cells fast enough. Push, shove.
JP9:41pm

except for, you know, its a non-cash charge or something

AS9:41pm

haven't you heard Jamie, add-backs are all the rage

9:41 pm
AS9:42pm

also check out their take on cash:

AS9:42pm

We received $112 million in net funding from our vehicle lease warehouse lines, automotive asset-backed notes, auto tax equity fund and collateralized lease borrowings. When combined with free cash flow, this is a better indicator of the cash consumed in the quarter.

JP9:42pm

worth noting that free cash flow came in below estimates, the street had -$978m, and Tesla burned through...

Brutto @JP - I liked the analysis and comments on stock based compensation at AV earlier today - but playing with Gross Profit....??? Not even the most inventive FAANG has done that, I think...
9:42 pm
AS9:43pm

but.... but is it? vehicle lease warehouse lines? Jamie do you know what the "auto tax equity fund" is?

JP9:43pm

$1.05bn

MontanaSkeptic No Model 3 leasing in 2018. This suggests to me we will not see any $36K Model 3 for sale. The target demographic remains the wealthy.
JP9:43pm

Alex, I have no idea. shall I google?

bones30 Brutto - how long before its FAAG I wonder?
9:43 pm
AS9:44pm

(heckuva lot of gross funding to get to net $112m)

AS9:44pm

I will post MontanaSkeptic's comment again (sorry Montana!)

AS9:45pm

No Model 3 leasing in 2018. This suggests to me we will not see any $36K Model 3 for sale. The target demographic remains the wealthy.

MontanaSkeptic I'm surprised to see the $50MM of ZEV credit revenues. Had thought they would save them for Q3.
9:46 pm
JP9:46pm

tbh the wealthy have proven a pretty good target demographic recently

AS9:46pm

aaand yet another comment has been blocked, because our tech system almost certainly functions worse than a Tesla Model 3 production line

Brutto bones- are you saying that burning cash forever to buy "growth" is unsustainable? Elon Musk, for one, would have something to say...
AS9:46pm

I'm surprised to see the $50MM of ZEV credit revenues. Had thought they would save them for Q3.

9:47 pm
AS9:47pm

(we've got you @MontanaSkeptic)

AS9:48pm

anyway wonder if that would show relative confidence about 2H vs 1Q

Ken M It's very strange for him to have painted himself into a corner with the pledge to not access capital markets.
bones30 They just need to get the machine that builds the machine that builds the machines working, then it'll all be easy.
Malcolm Tucker He did it before and then returned to the market so I guess it's a habit now
Ken M Tapping shareholders has been so easy for them to do for so long, I wonder why they've drawn that line in the sand.
AS9:49pm

I thought he was bullish on humans now @bones30

bones30 Ken: white or yellow line?
Driss SEC investigation
MontanaSkeptic GAAP Automotive Gross Margin of 19.7% and Tesla racked up loss of $709 million. That tells me lots of COGS are being pushed to operating expenses or being capitalized.
9:49 pm
JP9:49pm

the source of the next capital raise is an interesting one, not sure the debt markets will be that welcoming given the action on the 2025 recently...

Sean Wagner Don't make it more complicated - if they need to tap, they tap. The only thing that matters is ramping up production [and delivery...]. And the jury is out on that.
SupposeToBeWorking... @bones Musk won't have yellow in his factories
bones30 Exactly STBW
JP9:51pm

but then again, WeWork raised $700m odd so... ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

That New Car Smell Can we all agree the Model 3 is a beautiful car
Malcolm Tucker Only when the body panels' paint matches
AS9:52pm

more from MontanaSkeptic, because apparently our moderators are Tesla bulls or something

9:52 pm
AS9:52pm

GAAP Automotive Gross Margin of 19.7% and Tesla racked up loss of $709 million. That tells me lots of COGS are being pushed to operating expenses or being capitalized.

Sean Wagner Here's a bone: the first serious recall of Model 3 in substantial numbers will stress service centers mightily.
AS9:53pm

and at least they have assets Jamie

AS9:53pm

they being Tesla

Malcolm Tucker They already seem to be doing that pretty nicely without a recall
9:53 pm
JP9:53pm

of course

Sean Wagner P r e c i s e l y.
bones30 Always wanted a frunk.
JP9:54pm

as our colleague Rob Smith pointed out, the Gigafactory is still free to have debt secured against it

JP9:54pm

https://www.ft.com...-b5bf-23cb17fd1498

Malcolm Tucker How about a 911, bones?
Malcolm Tucker What is the value of the Gigafactory, though?
Malcolm Tucker Given that a large proportion of the equipment belongs to Panasonic
Phil Evening all!
9:56 pm
JP9:56pm

How long is a piece of string Malcolm?

Sean Wagner Sans Panasonic's very substantial investments.
AS9:56pm

hi Phil!

JP9:57pm

hey Phil!

MontanaSkeptic The fact that Tesla achieved a brilliant Automotive Gross Margin yet lost a record amount tells us how useless the highly manipulated Gross Margin metric has become. In no way comparable to gross margin at other automakers and, more importantly, NOT indicative of profitability.
9:57 pm
JP9:58pm

MontanaSkeptic with a good point there about profits falling but gross margin up

AS9:58pm

we seem to have just alerted the attention of our tech team w/r/t these comments, by the way

MontanaSkeptic Panasonic leases a huge piece of the Gigafactory for nominal rent. It can't be evicted even if Tesla is gone. Its lease is superior to any mortgage. The GF has little if any collateral value.
bones30 1024 Megafactories Malcolm?
AS9:59pm

the gross margin metric does indeed seem useless, montana. and wasn't there a big-name fund manager who said that tesla was a glorified battery company?

Malcolm Tucker Mr Baron, wasn't it?
Phil Musk makes for great entertainment. The true believers vs everyone else...
10:00 pm
AS10:00pm

if not even that bit has collateral value (as Montana has commented, once again hidden) that's bad news

AS10:00pm

Panasonic leases a huge piece of the Gigafactory for nominal rent. It can't be evicted even if Tesla is gone. Its lease is superior to any mortgage. The GF has little if any collateral value.

Teslashort it seems, between the lines, Teslay says that they are running out of capital and have to cut back on Capex
JP10:01pm

automotive leasing costs fell by $87m, so that might explain some of the swing.

Malcolm Tucker Has anyone offered an explanation for why the Gigafactory is 1/3 smaller than originally intended?
10:03 pm
JP10:03pm

Malcom - is it because battery tech doesn't scale? I dunno, just speculating.

Ops test
Sean Wagner They did find some time ago that cells and packs could be built with a lot less of a footprint than originally estimated.
Sean Wagner less of a manufacturing footprint
JP10:04pm

customer deposits also rose by $130m, which suggests demand for the M3 is still strong. unless some other cash is folded in there.

JP10:04pm

perhaps for the semi, or the roadster?

pinot nero test please ignore
10:04 pm
JP10:05pm

that being said, not all the roadsters have been reserved... https://www.tesla....eserve?redirect=no

Malcolm Tucker JP, that was kind of the whole thesis for the Gigafactory so...
MontanaSkeptic I think the explanations for why the GF is 1/3 the size promised are (a) Tesla gets much smaller subsidies from Nevada after the first $1B spend, and it is now past that, and (b) Tesla is producing less than 1/3 the number of Model 3s it said it would be producing by now. (GF makes cells for M3, but Tesla buys S & X cells from Panasonic's Asian factories.)
Ops test please ignore
Sean Wagner The Nevada tax credits are really not substantial.
Ops Ops Test
JP10:06pm

I know Malcolm, but times change

Ops Check
commentposter Testing comment
AS10:08pm

going to post MontanaSkeptic's latest comment again in the hopes some of the sharpness will accrue to me by association:

Malcolm Tucker Which is why mega, sorry, gigaprojects are often a bad idea///
10:08 pm
AS10:08pm

I think the explanations for why the GF is 1/3 the size promised are (a) Tesla gets much smaller subsidies from Nevada after the first $1B spend, and it is now past that, and (b) Tesla is producing less than 1/3 the number of Model 3s it said it would be producing by now. (GF makes cells for M3, but Tesla buys S & X cells from Panasonic's Asian factories.)

JP10:09pm

another astute MontanaSkeptic comment

Brutto Here's an interesting article of a potential M3 buyer (and self-declared value investor) on why he pulled out after putting down a deposit - gist: a properly optioned M£ will be closer to $50K than $35K - just not worth it...http://contrarianedge.com/2018/04/06/why-this-tesla-car-shopper-sped-away-from-the-model-3/
AS10:10pm

OK folks

10:10 pm
AS10:10pm

I fear we will have to leave the conference call to late-night London twitter

AS10:11pm

(thanks for the link @Brutto)

Ops Test
AS10:11pm

you all have approximately.... 20 minutes to get good and drunk before tweeting all-caps questions at Elon Musk

10:11 pm
JP10:11pm

many thanks to all the contributors

JP10:11pm

and precisely, 20 minutes to the teslaquilla gets opened

AS10:12pm

thanks everyone!

10:12 pm
JP10:12pm

thanks!

Phil M3 does seem to be astonishingly expensive when you compare it to equivalent vehicles from, say, Volvo or BMW. (Assuming you don't care /that/ much about the whole electric thing.) Hence comments about positional goods up top I guess...
Ops Check
originalTitle: Markets Live:  Tesla earnings special edition
subheading: Come chat about earnings, capital raises (or lack thereof) and Elon Musk.
standfirst: Come chat about earnings, capital raises (or lack thereof) and Elon Musk.
